column3: The two men looked at each other, and presently Burgess's eyes fell before those of the chaplain.

column2: Miserable blasphemer, says North, "I tell you that you shall not flog the boy."
column3: Miserable blasphemer, says North, "I tell you that you shall not flog the boy."

column2: Burgess, white with rage, rang the bell that summoned his convict servant.
column3: Burgess, white with rage, rang the bell that summoned his convict servant.

column2: Show Mr. North out, he said, "and go down to the Barracks, and tell Troke that Kirkland is to have a hundred lashes to-morrow.
column3: Show mr North out, he said, "and go down to the Barracks, and tell Troke that Kirkland is to have a hundred lashes to morrow.

column2: I'll show you who's master here, my good sir."
column3: I'll show you who's master here, my good sir."

column2: I'll report this to the Government, said North, aghast.
column3: I'll report this to the Government, said North, aghast.

column2: This is murderous.
column3: This is murderous.

column2: The Government may go to----, and you, too! roared Burgess.
column3: The Government may go to----, and you, too! roared Burgess.

column2: Get out! And God's viceregent at Port Arthur slammed the door.
column3: Get out! And God's viceregent at Port Arthur slammed the door.

column2: North returned home in great agitation.
column3: North returned home in great agitation.

column2: They shall not flog that boy, he said.
column3: They shall not flog that boy, he said.

column2: I'll shield him with my own body if necessary.	I'll shield him with my own body if necessary.

column2: I'll report this to the Government.
column3: I'll report this to the Government.

column2: I'll see Sir John Franklin myself.
column3: I'll see Sir john Franklin myself.

column2: I'll have the light of day let into this den of horrors." He reached his cottage, and lighted the lamp in the little sitting-room.
column3: I'll have the light of day let into this den of horrors." He reached his cottage, and lighted the lamp in the little sitting room.

column2: All was silent, save that from the adjoining chamber came the sound of Meekin's gentlemanly snore. North took down a book from the shelf and tried to read, but the letters ran together.
column3: All was silent, save that from the adjoining chamber came the sound of Meekin's gentlemanly snore. North took down a book from the shelf and tried to read, but the letters ran together.

column2: I wish I hadn't taken that brandy, he said.
column3: I wish I hadn't taken that brandy, he said.

column2: Fool that I am.
column3: Fool that I am.

column2: Then he began to walk up and down, to fling himself on the sofa, to read, to pray.
column3: Then he began to walk up and down, to fling himself on the sofa, to read, to pray.

column2: Oh, God, give me strength!	Oh, God, give me strength!
column3: true

column2: Aid me!
column3: Aid me!

column2: Help me!
column3: Help me!

column2: I struggle, but I am weak.
column3: I struggle, but I am weak.

column2: O, Lord, look down upon me!"
column3: O, Lord, look down upon me!"

column2: To see him rolling on the sofa in agony, to see his white face, his parched lips, and his contracted brow, to hear his moans and muttered prayers, one would have thought him suffering from the pangs of some terrible disease.
column3: To see him rolling on the sofa in agony, to see his white face, his parched lips, and his contracted brow, to hear his moans and muttered prayers, one would have thought him suffering from the pangs of some terrible disease.

column2: He opened the book again, and forced himself to read, but his eyes wandered to the cupboard.
column3: He opened the book again, and forced himself to read, but his eyes wandered to the cupboard.

column2: There lurked something that fascinated him.
column3: There lurked something that fascinated him.

column2: He got up at length, went into the kitchen, and found a packet of red pepper.
column3: He got up at length, went into the kitchen, and found a packet of red pepper.

column2: He mixed a teaspoonful of this in a pannikin of water and drank it.
column3: He mixed a teaspoonful of this in a pannikin of water and drank it.

column2: It relieved him for a while.
column3: It relieved him for a while.

column2: I must keep my wits for to-morrow.	I must keep my wits for to morrow.
column3: true

column2: The life of that lad depends upon it.
column3: The life of that lad depends upon it.

column2: Meekin, too, will suspect.
column3: Meekin, too, will suspect.

column2: I will lie down."
column3: I will lie down."

column2: He went into his bedroom and flung himself on the bed, but only to toss from side to side.
column3: He went into his bedroom and flung himself on the bed, but only to toss from side to side.

column2: In vain he repeated texts of Scripture and scraps of verse; in vain counted imaginary sheep, or listened to imaginary clock-tickings.
column3: In vain he repeated texts of Scripture and scraps of verse; in vain counted imaginary sheep, or listened to imaginary clock tickings.

column2: Sleep would not come to him.
column3: Sleep would not come to him.

column2: It was as though he had reached the crisis of a disease which had been for days gathering force. "I must have a teaspoonful," he said, "to allay the craving."
column3: It was as though he had reached the crisis of a disease which had been for days gathering force. "I must have a teaspoonful," he said, "to allay the craving."

column2: Twice he paused on the way to the sitting-room, and twice was he driven on by a power stronger than his will.
column3: Twice he paused on the way to the sitting room, and twice was he driven on by a power stronger than his will.

column2: He reached it at length, and opening the cupboard, pulled out what he sought.
column3: He reached it at length, and opening the cupboard, pulled out what he sought.

column2: A bottle of brandy. With this in his hand, all moderation vanished.
column3: A bottle of brandy. With this in his hand, all moderation vanished.

column2: He raised it to his lips and eagerly drank.
column3: He raised it to his lips and eagerly drank.

column2: Then, ashamed of what he had done, he thrust the bottle back, and made for his room.
column3: Then, ashamed of what he had done, he thrust the bottle back, and made for his room.

column2: Still he could not sleep.
column3: Still he could not sleep.

column2: The taste of the liquor maddened him for more.
column3: The taste of the liquor maddened him for more.

column2: He saw in the darkness the brandy bottle--vulgar and terrible apparition!
column3: He saw in the darkness the brandy bottle-vulgar and terrible apparition!

column2: He saw its amber fluid sparkle. He heard it gurgle as he poured it out.
column3: He saw its amber fluid sparkle. He heard it gurgle as he poured it out.

column2: He smelt the nutty aroma of the spirit.
column3: He smelt the nutty aroma of the spirit.

column2: He pictured it standing in the corner of the cupboard, and imagined himself seizing it and quenching the fire that burned within him.
column3: He pictured it standing in the corner of the cupboard, and imagined himself seizing it and quenching the fire that burned within him.

column2: He wept, he prayed, he fought with his desire as with a madness.
column3: He wept, he prayed, he fought with his desire as with a madness.

column2: He told himself that another's life depended on his exertions, that to give way to his fatal passion was unworthy of an educated man and a reasoning being, that it was degrading, disgusting, and bestial.
column3: He told himself that another's life depended on his exertions, that to give way to his fatal passion was unworthy of an educated man and a reasoning being, that it was degrading, disgusting, and bestial.

column2: That, at all times debasing, at this particular time it was infamous; that a vice, unworthy of any man, was doubly sinful in a man of education and a minister of God.
column3: That, at all times debasing, at this particular time it was infamous; that a vice, unworthy of any man, was doubly sinful in a man of education and a minister of God.

column2: In vain.
column3: In vain.

column2: In the midst of his arguments he found himself at the cupboard, with the bottle at his lips, in an attitude that was at once ludicrous and horrible.
column3: In the midst of his arguments he found himself at the cupboard, with the bottle at his lips, in an attitude that was at once ludicrous and horrible.

column2: He had no cancer.
column3: He had no cancer.

column2: His disease was a more terrible one.
column3: His disease was a more terrible one.

column2: The Reverend James North--gentleman, scholar, and Christian priest--was what the world calls "a confirmed drunkard".
column3: The Reverend james North-gentleman, scholar, and Christian priest-was what the world calls "a confirmed drunkard".
